elements.content: The luminescent Cu­(I) coordination polymers [Cu2I2(m,m′-bpy)] n (CuI- m; m,m′-bpy = m,m′-bipyridine; m = 3, 4) were successfully synthesized by the solvent-free thermal reaction of the metal salt CuI with the organic linkers m,m′-bpy. Powder X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that CuI-3 was immediately formed when a mixture of CuI and 3,3′-bpy was ground in a mortar at room temperature (20 °C). In contrast, a temperature >120 °C was required to synthesize the CuI-4 isomer, probably because of the higher melting point of the 4,4′-bpy linker. Although excess bpy linker was necessary to afford the CuI- m in high yield, the quantitative synthesis, without any purification processes, was successfully achieved by simple heating at 140 °C, whereby the excess bpy linker was thermally removed by evaporation. Single crystal X-ray structural analysis indicated that in CuI-3 the dinuclear {Cu2I2} rhombic cores were bridged by 3,3′-bpy linkers. A similar structure was observed for CuI-4; however, the intermolecular π–π stacking that was effective in CuI-4 was suppressed in CuI-3 because of the twisted configuration of the two pyridyl rings of the 3,3′-bpy linker. CuI-3 exhibited bright green emission with the maximum (λem) at 519 nm and a high emission quantum yield (Φ = 0.58) in the solid state at room temperature, in contrast to the weak red emission of CuI-4 (λem = 653 nm, Φ < 0.01). Emission decay analysis and density functional theory calculations suggested that the CuI- m emissions could be attributed to the delayed fluorescence from the metal-to-ligand charge-transfer excited state effectively mixed with the halide-to-ligand charge-transfer excited state.

A similar structure was observed for CuI-4; however, the intermolecular π-π stacking that was effective in CuI-4 was suppressed in CuI-3 because of the twisted configuration of the two pyridyl rings of the 3,3'-bpy linker. elements.content: Two thermally activated delayed fluorescent Cu­(I) coordination polymers (CPs), [Cu2I2(m,m′-bpy)2] n (m = 3, 4), composed of rhombic {Cu2I2} cores and bpy organic linkers, were quantitatively synthesized by thermal reaction in the absence of a solvent. Under these conditions, the thermal reaction was effective to (1) shorten the reaction time, (2) improve the yield, and (3) remove the excess organic linker. Photoluminescent properties of these CPs were discussed.

Under these conditions, the thermal reaction was effective to (1) shorten the reaction time, (2) improve the yield, and (3) remove the excess organic linker. Photoluminescent properties of these CPs were discussed.

elements.content: Luminescent Cu­(I) complexes have recently attracted considerable attention because of their interesting photophysical properties including high emission quantum yields and tunable emission colors. Moreover, due to the low cost and abundance of Cu resources, these complexes show great potential for industrial application as alternative materials to the luminescent noble metal Ru­(II), Ir­(III), and Pt­(II) complexes. The thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) of Cu­(I) complexes is a promising phenomenon, especially for application to organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs). For example, Yersin et al. reported that the bright blue TADF of the Cu­(I) complex [Cu­(pop)­(pz2BPh2)] {pop = bis­[2-(diphenylphosphino) phenyl]­ether; pz2BPh2 = bis­(pyrazol-1-yl)-biphenyl-borate} originated from the singlet and triplet metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) excited states. Moreover, Adachi et al. reported a promising OLED device containing a similar heteroleptic Cu­(I) complex [Cu­(dnbp)­(pop)]­BF4 (dnbp = 2,9-di-n-butylphenanthroline) that exhibited a high external quantum yield (EQE = 15.0%). These pioneering works clearly suggest that luminescent Cu­(I) complexes are a promising alternative to the phosphorescent noble metal complexes. However, the stability of Cu­(I) complexes, especially in solution, is generally lower than that of noble metal complexes such as the strongly emissive Ir­(III) complexes. Thus, this disadvantage must be overcome to enable the synthesis of solution-stable Cu­(I) complexes and the development of alternative techniques to the traditional solution reactions, strongly required for the preparation of thin-film light emitting devices based on Cu­(I) luminophores.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Luminescent Cu(I) complexes have recently attracted considerable attention because of their interesting photophysical properties including high emission quantum yields and tunable emission colors. Moreover, due to the low cost and abundance of Cu resources, these complexes show great potential for industrial application as alternative materials to the luminescent noble metal Ru(II), Ir(III), and Pt(II) complexes. The thermally activated delayed fluorescence (TADF) of Cu(I) complexes is a promising phenomenon, especially for application to organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs). For example, Yersin et al. reported that the bright blue TADF of the Cu(I) complex [Cu(pop)(pz2BPh2)] {pop = bis[2-(diphenylphosphino) phenyl]ether; pz2BPh2 = bis(pyrazol-1-yl)-biphenyl-borate} originated from the singlet and triplet metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) excited states. Moreover, Adachi et al. reported a promising OLED device containing a similar heteroleptic Cu(I) complex [Cu(dnbp)(pop)]BF4 (dnbp = 2,9-di-n-butylphenanthroline) that exhibited a high external quantum yield (EQE = 15.0%). These pioneering works clearly suggest that luminescent Cu(I) complexes are a promising alternative to the phosphorescent noble metal complexes. However, the stability of Cu(I) complexes, especially in solution, is generally lower than that of noble metal complexes such as the strongly emissive Ir(III) complexes. Thus, this disadvantage must be overcome to enable the synthesis of solution-stable Cu(I) complexes and the development of alternative techniques to the traditional solution reactions, strongly required for the preparation of thin-film light emitting devices based on Cu(I) luminophores.

elements.content: Over the past few decades, solvent-free mechanochemical synthesis has drawn considerable attention as an environmentally friendly synthetic method. This technique is potentially useful for the direct preparation of Cu­(I) luminophores on a substrate because no solvent (or a trace amount of solvent; assisting solvent) is required for the synthetic reaction. In fact, the mechanochemical synthesis of luminescent Cu­(I) complexes has been reported as an effective technique to minimize the use of a solvent as well as to shorten the reaction time and improve the yield. However, most mechanochemical syntheses of luminescent Cu­(I) complexes require an assisting solvent, while a washing process is necessary to remove the unreacted starting materials. We have previously reported a thermal synthesis without the use of an assisting solvent, which enabled us to synthesize luminescent Cu­(I) complexes via the melting of organic ligands to effectively promote complex formation. However, certain amounts of organic solvent were still necessary during the washing process. Thus, in this work, we have focused on thermally stable Cu­(I) coordination polymers because of (1) the high thermal stability of the coordination polymers, which allowed the removal of any unreacted materials, mainly excess organic ligands, via evaporation by simple heating and (2) the wide tunability of the emission color, from blue to red, which was achieved in the coordination polymeric system [Cu2I2(PPh3)­(L)] n (PPh3 = triphenylphosphine, L = N-heteroaromatic organic linkers). Herein, we report the completely solvent-free mechanochemical thermal synthesis of two simple Cu­(I) coordination polymers [Cu2I2(3,3′-bpy)] n and [Cu2I2(4,4′-bpy)] n (, CuI-3 and CuI-4, respectively; bpy = 3,3′- or 4,4′-bipyridine, respectively) with two isomeric bpy linkers. Heating of a ground mixture of CuI and the 3,3′- or 4,4′-bpy ligand (1:2 molar ratio) at 140 °C under Ar atmosphere afforded the respective CuI-3 and CuI-4 polymers quantitatively and no washing process was required. Furthermore, the replacement of the 4,4′-bpy with the 3,3′-bpy organic linker remarkably improved the emission quantum yield from <1 to 58% in the solid state at 298 K, despite the similar coordination network structure composed of rhombic {Cu2I2} cores and bpy linkers.

elements.content: Caution! Although we experienced no difficulties, all solvents used in this study are potentially harmful and should be used in small quantities and handled with care in a fume hood. All the commercially available starting materials were used as received and all the solvents were used without further purification. Unless otherwise stated, all manipulations were conducted in air. Elemental analysis was performed using a J-Science Lab MICRO CORDER JM 10 analyzer at the Analysis Center, Hokkaido University. Thermogravimetry and differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) were performed using a Rigaku ThermoEvo TG8120 analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

  Caution!  Although we experienced no difficulties, all solvents used in this study are potentially harmful and should be used in small quantities and handled with care in a fume hood. All the commercially available starting materials were used as received and all the solvents were used without further purification. Unless otherwise stated, all manipulations were conducted in air. Elemental analysis was performed using a J-Science Lab MICRO CORDER JM 10 analyzer at the Analysis Center, Hokkaido University. Thermogravimetry and differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) were performed using a Rigaku ThermoEvo TG8120 analyzer.

elements.content: The synthesis and crystal structure of CuI-3 has been previously reported. However, to compare its crystallographic parameters to those of CuI-4, CuI-3 was synthesized in this study using the following procedure: An acetonitrile solution (5 mL) of CuI (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) was added to a dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 5 mL) solution of 3,3′-bpy (33 mg, 0.21 mmol) at 298 K to produce a pale yellow precipitate. The product was allowed to stand for 1 week at 298 K, until yellow crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis emerged. The afforded yellow crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with small amounts of acetonitrile and diethyl ether, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 23.8 mg, 63%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C20H16Cu2I2N4: C: 34.65, H: 2.33, N: 8.08. Found: C: 34.35, H: 2.12, N: 7.89.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Cu2I2(3,3'-bpy)2] n  (CuI-3)

Preparation of CuI-3 as Single Crystals

The synthesis and crystal structure of CuI-3 has been previously reported. However, to compare its crystallographic parameters to those of CuI-4, CuI-3 was synthesized in this study using the following procedure: An acetonitrile solution (5 mL) of CuI (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) was added to a dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 5 mL) solution of 3,3'-bpy (33 mg, 0.21 mmol) at 298 K to produce a pale yellow precipitate. The product was allowed to stand for 1 week at 298 K, until yellow crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis emerged. The afforded yellow crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with small amounts of acetonitrile and diethyl ether, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 23.8 mg, 63%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C20H16Cu2I2N4: C: 34.65, H: 2.33, N: 8.08. Found: C: 34.35, H: 2.12, N: 7.89.

elements.content: CuI (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) and 3,3′-bpy (33 mg, 0.21 mmol) were mixed and manually ground with a mortar and pestle for 5 min. The ground mixture was then heated at 140 °C for 1 h under Ar flow (flow rate: 300 mL/min) to remove the excess 3,3′-bpy. The resulting yellow powder was manually collected with a spatula. Yield: 34.8 mg, 91%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C20H16Cu2I2N4: C: 34.65, H: 2.33, N: 8.08. Found: C: 34.99, H: 2.14, N: 8.04.

Grinding synthesis of CuI-3 

CuI (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) and 3,3'-bpy (33 mg, 0.21 mmol) were mixed and manually ground with a mortar and pestle for 5 min. The ground mixture was then heated at 140 °C for 1 h under Ar flow (flow rate: 300 mL/min) to remove the excess 3,3'-bpy. The resulting yellow powder was manually collected with a spatula. Yield: 34.8 mg, 91%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C20H16Cu2I2N4: C: 34.65, H: 2.33, N: 8.08. Found: C: 34.99, H: 2.14, N: 8.04.

elements.content: The synthesis and crystal structure of CuI-4 has been previously reported. However, to compare its crystallographic parameters to those of CuI-3, CuI-4 was synthesized in this study using the following procedure: A DMSO (5 mL) solution of 4,4′-bpy (33 mg, 0.21 mmol) was added to an acetonitrile solution (5 mL) of CuI (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) at 298 K to produce a yellow precipitate. The product was allowed to stand for 1 week at 298 K until red crystals emerged which were suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The afforded red crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with small amounts of acetonitrile and diethyl ether, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 35.2 mg, 92%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C20H16Cu2I2N4: C: 34.65, H: 2.33, N: 8.08. Found: C: 35.00, H: 2.16, N: 8.14.

Synthesis of [Cu2I2(4,4'-bpy)2] n  (CuI-4)

Preparation of CuI-4 as Single Crystals

The synthesis and crystal structure of CuI-4 has been previously reported. However, to compare its crystallographic parameters to those of CuI-3, CuI-4 was synthesized in this study using the following procedure: A DMSO (5 mL) solution of 4,4'-bpy (33 mg, 0.21 mmol) was added to an acetonitrile solution (5 mL) of CuI (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) at 298 K to produce a yellow precipitate. The product was allowed to stand for 1 week at 298 K until red crystals emerged which were suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The afforded red crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with small amounts of acetonitrile and diethyl ether, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 35.2 mg, 92%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C20H16Cu2I2N4: C: 34.65, H: 2.33, N: 8.08. Found: C: 35.00, H: 2.16, N: 8.14.

elements.content: CuI (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) and 4,4′-bpy (24.8 mg, 0.15 mmol) were mixed and manually ground with a mortar and pestle for 5 min. The mixture was then heated at 140 °C for 1 h under Ar flow (flow rate: 300 mL/min) to promote the coordination polymerization reaction between CuI and 4,4′-bpy and remove the excess 4,4′-bpy. The resulting red powder was manually collected with a spatula. Yield: 37.1 mg, 97%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C20H16Cu2I2N4: C: 34.65, H: 2.33, N: 8.08. Found: C: 34.46, H: 2.13, N: 7.93.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Synthesis of CuI-4 

CuI (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) and 4,4'-bpy (24.8 mg, 0.15 mmol) were mixed and manually ground with a mortar and pestle for 5 min. The mixture was then heated at 140 °C for 1 h under Ar flow (flow rate: 300 mL/min) to promote the coordination polymerization reaction between CuI and 4,4'-bpy and remove the excess 4,4'-bpy. The resulting red powder was manually collected with a spatula. Yield: 37.1 mg, 97%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C20H16Cu2I2N4: C: 34.65, H: 2.33, N: 8.08. Found: C: 34.46, H: 2.13, N: 7.93.

elements.content: The luminescence spectrum of each crystalline sample was measured using a JASCO FP-8600 spectrofluorometer. The luminescence quantum yields were determined using a Hamamatsu Photonics C9920–02 absolute photoluminescence quantum yield spectrometer fitted with an integrating sphere and a 150-W continuous-wave Xe light source. The emission lifetimes were determined using a Hamamatsu Photonics C4334 system equipped with a streak camera as the photodetector and a nitrogen laser as the excitation light source (λex = 337 nm). The sample temperature was controlled using a liquid-N2 cryostat (Optistat-DN optical Dewar and ITC-503 temperature controller, Oxford Instruments). Emission decays were analyzed using two exponentials: I = A 1 ⁡ exp ( − t / τ 1 ) + A 2 ⁡ exp ( − t / τ 2 ) where τ1 and τ2 are the lifetimes and A 1 and A 2 are the pre-exponential factors. The average lifetimes (τav) were used to determine the radiative and nonradiative rate constants of the two exponential decay components using : τ av = ( A 1 τ 1 2 + A 2 τ 2 2 ) / ( A 1 τ 1 + A 2 τ 2 )
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Measurements

The luminescence spectrum of each crystalline sample was measured using a JASCO FP-8600 spectrofluorometer. The luminescence quantum yields were determined using a Hamamatsu Photonics C9920-02 absolute photoluminescence quantum yield spectrometer fitted with an integrating sphere and a 150-W continuous-wave Xe light source. The emission lifetimes were determined using a Hamamatsu Photonics C4334 system equipped with a streak camera as the photodetector and a nitrogen laser as the excitation light source (λex = 337 nm). The sample temperature was controlled using a liquid-N2 cryostat (Optistat-DN optical Dewar and ITC-503 temperature controller, Oxford Instruments). Emission decays were analyzed using two exponentials: 1     I =   A   1   ⁡ exp  ( - t /   τ   1   )  +   A   2   ⁡ exp  ( - t /   τ   2   )     where τ1 and τ2 are the lifetimes and A 1 and A 2 are the pre-exponential factors. The average lifetimes (τav) were used to determine the radiative and nonradiative rate constants of the two exponential decay components using :  2       τ   av   =  (   A   1     τ   1   2   +   A   2     τ   2   2   )  /  (   A   1     τ   1   +   A   2     τ   2   )

elements.content: PXRD measurements were conducted using a Rigaku SPD diffractometer at the BL-8B beamline of the Photon Factory, KEK, Japan or a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator using Cu Kα radiation and a one-dimensional (1D) LinxEye detector. The synchrotron X-ray wavelength was 1.5455(1) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD)

PXRD measurements were conducted using a Rigaku SPD diffractometer at the BL-8B beamline of the Photon Factory, KEK, Japan or a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator using Cu Kα radiation and a one-dimensional (1D) LinxEye detector. The synchrotron X-ray wavelength was 1.5455(1) Å.

elements.content: CuI-3 and CuI-4 SXRD data were collected using a Rigaku XtaLAB synergy diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation [PhotonJet­(Cu)]. Each crystal was mounted on a MicroMount using paraffin oil. The crystal was then cooled using a N2-flow-type temperature controller. The diffraction data were processed using CrysAlisPRO software. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinement using SHELXL. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, while the hydrogen atoms were refined using the riding model. All calculations were performed using the Olex2 software package. The crystallographic data obtained for each complex are listed in . Full crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC 1886407 and 1886408).
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction (SXRD)

 CuI-3 and CuI-4 SXRD data were collected using a Rigaku XtaLAB synergy diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation [PhotonJet(Cu)]. Each crystal was mounted on a MicroMount using paraffin oil. The crystal was then cooled using a N2-flow-type temperature controller. The diffraction data were processed using CrysAlisPRO software. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinement using SHELXL. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, while the hydrogen atoms were refined using the riding model. All calculations were performed using the Olex2 software package. The crystallographic data obtained for each complex are listed in . Full crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC 1886407 and 1886408).

All density functional theory (DFT) calculations for the simplified model complexes [Cu2I2(n-phpy)4] (CuI- m ph; m-phpy = m-phenylpyridine, m = 3, 4) were performed using the Gaussian 09W program. The Cartesian coordinates of these two model complexes were generated from the experimentally determined X-ray structures of CuI-3 and CuI-4 by replacing four N–Cu bonds with C–H bonds and geometry optimization was skipped to retain the structural features. The single point calculations were achieved using the Becke3LYP functional as implemented in the Gaussian09 program. In these calculations, the SDD basis sets and the associated effective core potentials were used for Cu and I, while the 6-31G­(d) basis sets were used for the remaining atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Methods

All density functional theory (DFT) calculations for the simplified model complexes [Cu2I2(n-phpy)4] (CuI- m ph; m-phpy = m-phenylpyridine, m = 3, 4) were performed using the Gaussian 09W program. The Cartesian coordinates of these two model complexes were generated from the experimentally determined X-ray structures of CuI-3 and CuI-4 by replacing four N-Cu bonds with C-H bonds and geometry optimization was skipped to retain the structural features. The single point calculations were achieved using the Becke3LYP functional as implemented in the Gaussian09 program. In these calculations, the SDD basis sets and the associated effective core potentials were used for Cu and I, while the 6-31G(d) basis sets were used for the remaining atoms.

elements.content: As mentioned in the introduction, the melt of an organic ligand is an important step for the formation of luminescent mono- and dinuclear Cu­(I) complexes. Thus, solvent-free thermal synthesis of CuI- m (m = 3, 4) was conducted to verify the validity of this strategy for the synthesis of luminescent Cu­(I) coordination polymers. a presents the PXRD measurements of the samples obtained from the thermal synthesis of CuI-4. The PXRD pattern of the ground CuI and 4,4′-bpy (1:2 molar ratio) mixture without heating was near-identical to that of the organic ligand 4,4′-bpy with a strong diffraction peak derived from CuI, indicating that no reaction occurred in the grinding process at room temperature. Conversely, after heating the ground mixture at 140 °C for 1 h, the pattern changed significantly and was almost identical to the simulated pattern based on the reported crystal structure of CuI-4. In addition, the color of the ground mixture drastically changed from a nonemissive yellow powder [prior to heating; b] to a red emissive powder [after heating; c]. Thus, the coordination polymer CuI-4 was successfully synthesized by heating the ground mixture at 140 °C, a temperature that is higher the melting point of 4,4′-bpy (∼110 °C). Notably, a near-identical pattern to that of the simulation was also obtained by changing the CuI/4,4′-bpy molar ratio from 1:2 to 1:1.5, while the strong peak derived from the unreacted CuI was still observed at 25.6° for the mixture with a 1:1 molar ratio. This dependence on the molar ratio of the starting materials clearly indicates that an excess amount of 4,4′-bpy was required to consume all the CuI starting material and quantitatively synthesize the target complex CuI-4. Thus, to elucidate the reaction temperature required to form CuI-4, TG-DTA was next conducted on the CuI/4:4′-bpy (1:1.5 molar ratio) ground mixture [b]. The endothermic peak observed at 110 °C was assigned to the melting of the 4,4′-bpy ligand in the ground mixture. Moreover, a marked exothermic peak at 112 °C, which is slightly higher than the melting point of 4,4′-bpy, was assigned to the heat of formation of CuI-4 because: (1) A PXRD pattern near-identical to that of the ground mixture in the absence of heating was observed below this temperature (Figure S1). (2) No phase transition was observed for CuI-4 below 150 °C (Figure S2). Notably, the observed weight loss after heating at 140 °C for 1 h (−18.35%) was quantitatively in agreement with the mass of the excess 4,4′-bpy ligand (0.5 equiv = 18.39%), suggesting that the excess ligand could be easily removed by heating without any decomposition of the target complex. Thus, the quantitative synthesis of CuI-4 was easily achieved by simple heating of the CuI and 4,4′-bpy ground mixture at 140 °C in the absence of a washing process. This was supported by the elemental analysis data for the sample obtained by thermal synthesis (section entitled “”). However, a further increase in the reaction temperature would be difficult because CuI-4 releases half of the bpy linker at the range 170–230 °C (Figure S2). We have tried to synthesize CuI-4 quantitatively based on the mechanochemical method in the presence of small amount of CH3CN assisting solvent. The PXRD patterns of the samples obtained from the 5 and 10 min grinding at 293 K indicate that most of the starting metal salt CuI was remained and only small amount of CuI-4 was produced (Figure S3). Thus, the solvent-assisting mechanochemical method is not effective for the synthesis of luminescent coordination polymer CuI-4. Although the reason is still under investigation, it might be due to the slow diffusion of the bridging 4,4′-bpy ligand into the CuI solid and/or the poor solubility of CuI-4 to the assisting CH3CN solvent.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Solvent-Free Thermal Synthesis

As mentioned in the introduction, the melt of an organic ligand is an important step for the formation of luminescent mono- and dinuclear Cu(I) complexes. Thus, solvent-free thermal synthesis of CuI- m (m = 3, 4) was conducted to verify the validity of this strategy for the synthesis of luminescent Cu(I) coordination polymers. a presents the PXRD measurements of the samples obtained from the thermal synthesis of CuI-4. The PXRD pattern of the ground CuI and 4,4'-bpy (1:2 molar ratio) mixture without heating was near-identical to that of the organic ligand 4,4'-bpy with a strong diffraction peak derived from CuI, indicating that no reaction occurred in the grinding process at room temperature. Conversely, after heating the ground mixture at 140 °C for 1 h, the pattern changed significantly and was almost identical to the simulated pattern based on the reported crystal structure of CuI-4. In addition, the color of the ground mixture drastically changed from a nonemissive yellow powder [prior to heating; b] to a red emissive powder [after heating; c]. Thus, the coordination polymer CuI-4 was successfully synthesized by heating the ground mixture at 140 °C, a temperature that is higher the melting point of 4,4'-bpy (~110 °C). Notably, a near-identical pattern to that of the simulation was also obtained by changing the CuI/4,4'-bpy molar ratio from 1:2 to 1:1.5, while the strong peak derived from the unreacted CuI was still observed at 25.6° for the mixture with a 1:1 molar ratio. This dependence on the molar ratio of the starting materials clearly indicates that an excess amount of 4,4'-bpy was required to consume all the CuI starting material and quantitatively synthesize the target complex CuI-4. Thus, to elucidate the reaction temperature required to form CuI-4, TG-DTA was next conducted on the CuI/4:4'-bpy (1:1.5 molar ratio) ground mixture [b]. The endothermic peak observed at 110 °C was assigned to the melting of the 4,4'-bpy ligand in the ground mixture. Moreover, a marked exothermic peak at 112 °C, which is slightly higher than the melting point of 4,4'-bpy, was assigned to the heat of formation of CuI-4 because: (1) A PXRD pattern near-identical to that of the ground mixture in the absence of heating was observed below this temperature (Figure S1). (2) No phase transition was observed for CuI-4 below 150 °C (Figure S2). Notably, the observed weight loss after heating at 140 °C for 1 h (-18.35%) was quantitatively in agreement with the mass of the excess 4,4'-bpy ligand (0.5 equiv = 18.39%), suggesting that the excess ligand could be easily removed by heating without any decomposition of the target complex. Thus, the quantitative synthesis of CuI-4 was easily achieved by simple heating of the CuI and 4,4'-bpy ground mixture at 140 °C in the absence of a washing process. This was supported by the elemental analysis data for the sample obtained by thermal synthesis (section entitled ""). However, a further increase in the reaction temperature would be difficult because CuI-4 releases half of the bpy linker at the range 170-230 °C (Figure S2). We have tried to synthesize CuI-4 quantitatively based on the mechanochemical method in the presence of small amount of CH3CN assisting solvent. The PXRD patterns of the samples obtained from the 5 and 10 min grinding at 293 K indicate that most of the starting metal salt CuI was remained and only small amount of CuI-4 was produced (Figure S3). Thus, the solvent-assisting mechanochemical method is not effective for the synthesis of luminescent coordination polymer CuI-4. Although the reason is still under investigation, it might be due to the slow diffusion of the bridging 4,4'-bpy ligand into the CuI solid and/or the poor solubility of CuI-4 to the assisting CH3CN solvent.

elements.content: Since the melting point of 3,3′-bpy is remarkably lower than that of 4,4′-bpy and 3,3′-bpy is in the liquid state at room temperature, the thermal synthesis of CuI-3 was also examined. The changes of the PXRD pattern for this synthesis are presented in . In contrast to the negligible change in the PXRD pattern of the CuI and 4,4′-bpy mixture, the CuI and 3,3′-bpy (molar ratio = 1:2) ground mixture in the absence of heat exhibited a completely different pattern to that of CuI, which was almost identical to that of the simulation calculated from the reported crystal structure of CuI-3. Considering that the observed PXRD pattern was not changed by washing with Et2O, the luminescent coordination polymer, CuI-3 was simply obtained by simply mixing CuI powder with 3,3′-bpy liquid in mortar with a pestle at room temperature. Furthermore, a PXRD pattern that was near-identical to the simulated pattern was also observed by heating the ground mixture at 140 °C for 1 h to thermally remove the excess 3,3′-bpy. The elemental analysis for the heated sample was in good agreement with the calculated CuI-3 values, indicating that the excess 3,3′-bpy was successfully removed by simple heating to afford CuI-3 quantitatively. Although the further increase of reaction temperature caused the loss of bridging 3,3′-bpy ligand from CuI-3 as suggested by TG-DTA analysis (Figure S2), the starting material CuI was recovered by the heating at 400 °C of CuI- m in Ar atmosphere (Figure S4). Since the released bpy in both the thermal synthesis and the recycle process of CuI could be reusable, the thermally synthesized CuI- m would be ideal luminescent materials from the viewpoint of atom economy.

elements.content: Although the crystal structures of CuI-3 and CuI-4 have already been reported in the literature, single crystal X-ray structure analysis was performed to precisely compare the structures of the crystals formed under the same experimental conditions and reveal the origin of the remarkably different photoluminescence properties of these coordination polymers (see the section entitled “”). illustrates the X-ray crystal structures of CuI-3 and CuI-4, while selected bond lengths and angles around the Cu­(I) cation are listed in . The unit cells of both structures comprised one crystallographically independent Cu cation, one I– anion, and one bpy ligand. Moreover, the Cu cations in both CuI-3 and CuI-4 commonly adopted a tetrahedral coordination geometry with two I– anions and two N atoms of the bpy ligand; this is the typical structure of the monovalent Cu­(I) cation. Thus, the two I– anions were bridged between two adjacent Cu­(I) cations to form a similar dinuclear rhombic {Cu2I2} core structure. One dinuclear {Cu2I2} core was bridged by four bpy ligands to form a 2D coordination sheet on the (101) plane in CuI-3 and (110) plane in CuI-4. Notably, the two adjacent planar-shaped 4,4′-bpy bridging ligands completely overlapped in the hexagonal coordination sheet structure of CuI-4, while the two pyridyl rings of the bridging 3,3′-bpy ligand in CuI-3 were not on the same plane but displayed a torsion angle of 43.2(6)°. Because of the twisted structure of the bridging 3,3′-bpy, only the edge-to-edge-type π–π stacking was observed at a distance of 3.37(1) Å [a]. The Cu–N bond distances in CuI-3 were comparable to those in CuI-4; however, the former were slightly longer by ∼0.03 Å (). Notably, the Cu···Cu distance in the rhombic core in CuI-3 was significantly shorter (by ∼0.15 Å) than that in CuI-4 and shorter than twice the van der Waals radius of Cu (2.80 Å), suggesting effective Cu···Cu interactions in the rhombic core. In addition, the crystal density of CuI-3 (2.195 g·cm–3) was slightly larger than that of CuI-4 (2.193 g·cm–3), even at the same chemical composition, indicating a more tightly packed coordination network structure of CuI-3 over that of CuI-4.

Crystal Structures of CuI-m 

Although the crystal structures of CuI-3 and CuI-4 have already been reported in the literature, single crystal X-ray structure analysis was performed to precisely compare the structures of the crystals formed under the same experimental conditions and reveal the origin of the remarkably different photoluminescence properties of these coordination polymers (see the section entitled "").  illustrates the X-ray crystal structures of CuI-3 and CuI-4, while selected bond lengths and angles around the Cu(I) cation are listed in . The unit cells of both structures comprised one crystallographically independent Cu cation, one I- anion, and one bpy ligand. Moreover, the Cu cations in both CuI-3 and CuI-4 commonly adopted a tetrahedral coordination geometry with two I- anions and two N atoms of the bpy ligand; this is the typical structure of the monovalent Cu(I) cation. Thus, the two I- anions were bridged between two adjacent Cu(I) cations to form a similar dinuclear rhombic {Cu2I2} core structure. One dinuclear {Cu2I2} core was bridged by four bpy ligands to form a 2D coordination sheet on the (101) plane in CuI-3 and (110) plane in CuI-4. Notably, the two adjacent planar-shaped 4,4'-bpy bridging ligands completely overlapped in the hexagonal coordination sheet structure of CuI-4, while the two pyridyl rings of the bridging 3,3'-bpy ligand in CuI-3 were not on the same plane but displayed a torsion angle of 43.2(6)°. Because of the twisted structure of the bridging 3,3'-bpy, only the edge-to-edge-type π-π stacking was observed at a distance of 3.37(1) Å [a]. The Cu-N bond distances in CuI-3 were comparable to those in CuI-4; however, the former were slightly longer by ~0.03 Å (). Notably, the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance in the rhombic core in CuI-3 was significantly shorter (by ~0.15 Å) than that in CuI-4 and shorter than twice the van der Waals radius of Cu (2.80 Å), suggesting effective Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu interactions in the rhombic core. In addition, the crystal density of CuI-3 (2.195 g⋅cm-3) was slightly larger than that of CuI-4 (2.193 g⋅cm-3), even at the same chemical composition, indicating a more tightly packed coordination network structure of CuI-3 over that of CuI-4.

elements.content: As mentioned in the , luminescent Cu­(I) complexes are the predicted alternatives of luminescent noble metal complexes such as Ru­(II), Ir­(III), and Pt­(II) complexes. Although the photophysical properties of both CuI-3 and CuI-4 have been briefly investigated at room temperature, this study investigates the photophysical properties of CuI- m to elucidate the replacing effect of the bpy ligand. The observed excitation and emission spectra of CuI-3 and CuI-4 obtained from the solution reaction in the solid state at 298 and 77 K are presented in . As illustrated in the insets in , the crystal colors were completely different: the CuI-3 crystals appeared pale-yellow in the bright-field image and displayed bright green emission under UV light irradiation, as reported in the literature. Conversely, the red CuI-4 crystals exhibited weak red emission under UV light irradiation as illustrated in the bright-field and luminescence photographs. Both complexes exhibited similar broad emission bands without vibrational progressions, suggesting that the emission could be derived from the charge-transfer excited state. However, the emission band of CuI-3 was observed at a shorter wavelength (by >100 nm) than that of CuI-4 at both temperatures. A similar difference between CuI-3 and CuI-4 was observed in the excitation spectra; the excitation band edge of CuI-3 was at a wavelength ∼100 nm shorter than that of CuI-4. These results clearly indicate that the positions of the coordination N atoms in the bridging bipyridine ligand have a significant effect on the photophysical properties of the two complexes. The qualitatively identical emission spectra were observed for the samples prepared by grinding and thermal synthesis (Figure S5). Although some Cu­(I) coordination polymers exhibited interesting vapo- and thermochromic luminescence, these CuI- m coordination polymers did not exhibit vapochromic luminescence under exposure to water, EtOH, or CH3CN vapor probably due to the stable nonporous structures supported by the bridging m,m′-bpy ligands (Figures S6 and S7).

Photophysical Properties

As mentioned in the , luminescent Cu(I) complexes are the predicted alternatives of luminescent noble metal complexes such as Ru(II), Ir(III), and Pt(II) complexes. Although the photophysical properties of both CuI-3 and CuI-4 have been briefly investigated at room temperature, this study investigates the photophysical properties of CuI- m to elucidate the replacing effect of the bpy ligand. The observed excitation and emission spectra of CuI-3 and CuI-4 obtained from the solution reaction in the solid state at 298 and 77 K are presented in . As illustrated in the insets in , the crystal colors were completely different: the CuI-3 crystals appeared pale-yellow in the bright-field image and displayed bright green emission under UV light irradiation, as reported in the literature. Conversely, the red CuI-4 crystals exhibited weak red emission under UV light irradiation as illustrated in the bright-field and luminescence photographs. Both complexes exhibited similar broad emission bands without vibrational progressions, suggesting that the emission could be derived from the charge-transfer excited state. However, the emission band of CuI-3 was observed at a shorter wavelength (by >100 nm) than that of CuI-4 at both temperatures. A similar difference between CuI-3 and CuI-4 was observed in the excitation spectra; the excitation band edge of CuI-3 was at a wavelength ~100 nm shorter than that of CuI-4. These results clearly indicate that the positions of the coordination N atoms in the bridging bipyridine ligand have a significant effect on the photophysical properties of the two complexes. The qualitatively identical emission spectra were observed for the samples prepared by grinding and thermal synthesis (Figure S5). Although some Cu(I) coordination polymers exhibited interesting vapo- and thermochromic luminescence, these CuI- m coordination polymers did not exhibit vapochromic luminescence under exposure to water, EtOH, or CH3CN vapor probably due to the stable nonporous structures supported by the bridging m,m'-bpy ligands (Figures S6 and S7).

elements.content: To further investigate the photophysical properties of the two complexes, the emission lifetimes and quantum yields of the two coordination polymers were estimated at 298 and 77 K in the solid state (). Interesting differences between CuI-3 and CuI-4 were observed for both temperatures: The emission quantum yields of CuI-3 (0.58 and 0.80 at 298 and 77 K, respectively) were remarkably higher than those of CuI-4 (<0.01 and 0.04 at 298 and 77 K, respectively). Similarly, the observed emission decay of CuI-3 was remarkably longer than that of CuI-4 (Figure S8). Although the emission decays were analyzed using two exponential decays ( in the “” section), the dependence of the time-resolved emission spectra of CuI- m, at both 298 and 77 K, on the measurement time range was negligible (Figure S9). This suggested that only one emission species contributes to their luminescence behavior. Thus, the emission decay was next analyzed, using to calculate the averaged emission lifetimes and estimate the radiative and nonradiative rate constants (k r and k nr) based the on the average lifetimes and emission quantum yields (). The k r values of these two coordination polymers were comparable, while the k nr value of CuI-3 was 2 orders of magnitude smaller than that of CuI-4. Thus, the emissions of both CuI-3 and CuI-4 should originate from a similar charge-transfer excited state, as suggested by the similarly broadened emission band shape. However, the nonradiative decay of CuI-3 was more effectively suppressed, even at 298 K, by the higher emission wavelength (energy gap law) as well as the tightly packed crystal structure, as suggested by the larger crystal density. One noteworthy difference was observed for CuI-3 obtained from the thermal synthesis (Figure S8 and ). Although the emission lifetime and quantum yield at 77 K of both CuI-3 samples were comparable, the thermally synthesized CuI-3 exhibited shorter lifetime and smaller quantum yield at 298 K than those of CuI-3 obtained from the solution reaction. The three times larger k nr value suggests that nonemissive impurity and/or defect sites could be generated in the thermally synthesized CuI-3. Considering that excess amount of 3,3′-bpy ligand was used in the thermal synthesis, the intermolecular interaction like π–π stacking among the ligands on the crystal surface might produce such the thermally accessible nonemissive state.

To acquire further insight into the emission origins of these coordination polymers, density-functional theory (DFT) calculations were next conducted for the simplified dinuclear complexes, CuI- m ph ([Cu2I2(m-phpy)4]; m-phpy = m-phenylpyridine, m = 3, 4). To retain the characteristic features of the crystal structures of CuI-3 and CuI-4, the coordination geometries were fixed as their X-ray structures in the calculations, except for the replacement of one of the N–Cu bonds of each bpy ligands to a C–H bond (replacing the ligand from m,m′-bpy to m-phpy). The schematic MO diagrams for both complexes are displayed in . A similar trend was observed for both complexes: The HOMO and HOMO–1 were mainly composed of Cu 3d and I 5p orbitals, while the LUMO and LUMO+1 were localized on the π* orbitals of the phpy ligands. Notably, the LUMO of CuI-4ph was more stable (by ∼0.54 eV) than that of CuI-3ph because of the effective π–π stacking between the two adjacent phpy ligands, as suggested by the MO shape. In addition, the energies of the HOMO and HOMO+1 of CuI-4ph were higher (by ∼0.2 eV) than those of CuI-3ph, probably due to the stronger σ-donating ability of 4-phpy over that of 3-phpy. As a result, the energy gap between the HOMO and LUMO of CuI-3ph was remarkably higher (by ∼0.7 eV) than that of CuI-4ph. These results are in qualitative agreement with the higher emission energy of CuI-3 (by ∼0.5 eV) over that of CuI-4 at 298 K in the solid state. Thus, the emission origin of the coordination polymer CuI- m (m = 3, 4) was attributed to the emission from the charge-transfer excited state from the rhombic {Cu2I2} core to the π* orbital of bpy ligand, i.e., the (M+X)­LCT excited state. In addition, the HOMOs and LUMOs were well separated at the rhombic {Cu2I2} core and the m-phpy ligand, respectively, suggesting a small energy difference between the 1(M+X)­LCT and 3(M+X)­LCT excited states. Furthermore, the radiative rate constant of CuI-3 decreased by about a third when the temperature was decreased to 77 K (). Thus, we concluded that the emission of CuI- m could be attributed to the delayed fluorescence from the 1(M+X)­LCT excited state at 298 K and changed to simple phosphorescence from the same triplet excited state at 77 K. In fact, the emission lifetime of CuI-3 was decreased with increasing temperature, and the two-state model fitting analysis revealed that the energy difference between the S1 and T1 states (505 cm–1) is small enough for the thermal activation from T1 to S1 at around 298 K (Figure S10). Considering that the lowest unoccupied Cu–Cu bonding orbital was LUMO+19, with an energy 2.4 eV higher than that of the LUMO (Figures S11 and S12), the contribution of the triplet cluster-centered (3CC) emission to the emission property of CuI- m would be negligible.
elements.clean_text: To acquire further insight into the emission origins of these coordination polymers, density-functional theory (DFT) calculations were next conducted for the simplified dinuclear complexes, CuI- m ph ([Cu2I2(m-phpy)4]; m-phpy = m-phenylpyridine, m = 3, 4). To retain the characteristic features of the crystal structures of CuI-3 and CuI-4, the coordination geometries were fixed as their X-ray structures in the calculations, except for the replacement of one of the N-Cu bonds of each bpy ligands to a C-H bond (replacing the ligand from m,m'-bpy to m-phpy). The schematic MO diagrams for both complexes are displayed in . A similar trend was observed for both complexes: The HOMO and HOMO-1 were mainly composed of Cu 3d and I 5p orbitals, while the LUMO and LUMO+1 were localized on the π* orbitals of the phpy ligands. Notably, the LUMO of CuI-4ph was more stable (by ~0.54 eV) than that of CuI-3ph because of the effective π-π stacking between the two adjacent phpy ligands, as suggested by the MO shape. In addition, the energies of the HOMO and HOMO+1 of CuI-4ph were higher (by ~0.2 eV) than those of CuI-3ph, probably due to the stronger σ-donating ability of 4-phpy over that of 3-phpy. As a result, the energy gap between the HOMO and LUMO of CuI-3ph was remarkably higher (by ~0.7 eV) than that of CuI-4ph. These results are in qualitative agreement with the higher emission energy of CuI-3 (by ~0.5 eV) over that of CuI-4 at 298 K in the solid state. Thus, the emission origin of the coordination polymer CuI- m (m = 3, 4) was attributed to the emission from the charge-transfer excited state from the rhombic {Cu2I2} core to the π* orbital of bpy ligand, i.e., the (M+X)LCT excited state. In addition, the HOMOs and LUMOs were well separated at the rhombic {Cu2I2} core and the m-phpy ligand, respectively, suggesting a small energy difference between the 1(M+X)LCT and 3(M+X)LCT excited states. Furthermore, the radiative rate constant of CuI-3 decreased by about a third when the temperature was decreased to 77 K (). Thus, we concluded that the emission of CuI- m could be attributed to the delayed fluorescence from the 1(M+X)LCT excited state at 298 K and changed to simple phosphorescence from the same triplet excited state at 77 K. In fact, the emission lifetime of CuI-3 was decreased with increasing temperature, and the two-state model fitting analysis revealed that the energy difference between the S1 and T1 states (505 cm-1) is small enough for the thermal activation from T1 to S1 at around 298 K (Figure S10). Considering that the lowest unoccupied Cu-Cu bonding orbital was LUMO+19, with an energy 2.4 eV higher than that of the LUMO (Figures S11 and S12), the contribution of the triplet cluster-centered (3CC) emission to the emission property of CuI- m would be negligible.

elements.content: The luminescent Cu­(I) coordination polymers CuI-3 and CuI-4 were synthesized by both a traditional solution reaction and a thermal solvent-free synthetic reaction. The temperatures required to form these coordination polymers were completely different. Thus, CuI-3 was synthesized without heating, while a temperature >120 °C was required for the synthesis of CuI-4, probably due to the higher melting point of 4,4′-bpy over that of 3,3′-bpy. Both complexes were successfully synthesized quantitatively in the absence of an organic solvent by thermal reaction at 140 °C, where the excess amount of the bpy ligand could be removed by evaporation. CuI-3 complex exhibited a remarkably shorter-wavelength emission and higher emission quantum yield (λ = 519 nm, Φ = 0.58 at 298 K in the solid state) than those of CuI-4 (λ= 653 nm, Φ < 0.01). X-ray structure analysis of CuI-3 clearly revealed that a rhombic {Cu2I2} core, similar to that of CuI-4, was formed in the coordination network structure; however, the intermolecular π–π stacking that was effective in CuI-4 was suppressed by the twisted conformation of the two pyridyl rings of the 3,3′-bpy bridging ligand. DFT calculations for the simplified dinuclear complexes and emission lifetime analysis suggested that the luminescence of CuI- m (m = 3, 4) at 298 K could be assignable to the delayed-fluorescence from the (M+X)­LCT excited states. Further study on thermal syntheses in the absence of organic solvents for various colored Cu­(I) emissive complexes is in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The luminescent Cu(I) coordination polymers CuI-3 and CuI-4 were synthesized by both a traditional solution reaction and a thermal solvent-free synthetic reaction. The temperatures required to form these coordination polymers were completely different. Thus, CuI-3 was synthesized without heating, while a temperature >120 °C was required for the synthesis of CuI-4, probably due to the higher melting point of 4,4'-bpy over that of 3,3'-bpy. Both complexes were successfully synthesized quantitatively in the absence of an organic solvent by thermal reaction at 140 °C, where the excess amount of the bpy ligand could be removed by evaporation. CuI-3 complex exhibited a remarkably shorter-wavelength emission and higher emission quantum yield (λ = 519 nm, Φ = 0.58 at 298 K in the solid state) than those of CuI-4 (λ= 653 nm, Φ < 0.01). X-ray structure analysis of CuI-3 clearly revealed that a rhombic {Cu2I2} core, similar to that of CuI-4, was formed in the coordination network structure; however, the intermolecular π-π stacking that was effective in CuI-4 was suppressed by the twisted conformation of the two pyridyl rings of the 3,3'-bpy bridging ligand. DFT calculations for the simplified dinuclear complexes and emission lifetime analysis suggested that the luminescence of CuI- m (m = 3, 4) at 298 K could be assignable to the delayed-fluorescence from the (M+X)LCT excited states. Further study on thermal syntheses in the absence of organic solvents for various colored Cu(I) emissive complexes is in progress.

cln_elements.content:
The synthesis and crystal structure of CuI-3 has been previously reported. However, to compare its crystallographic parameters to those of CuI-4, CuI-3 was synthesized in this study using the following procedure: An acetonitrile solution (5 mL) of CuI (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) was added to a dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, 5 mL) solution of 3,3′-bpy (33 mg, 0.21 mmol) at 298 K to produce a pale yellow precipitate. The product was allowed to stand for 1 week at 298 K, until yellow crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis emerged. The afforded yellow crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with small amounts of acetonitrile and diethyl ether, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 23.8 mg, 63%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C20H16Cu2I2N4: C: 34.65, H: 2.33, N: 8.08. Found: C: 34.35, H: 2.12, N: 7.89.

Grinding synthesis of <bold>CuI-3</bold>

CuI (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) and 3,3′-bpy (33 mg, 0.21 mmol) were mixed and manually ground with a mortar and pestle for 5 min. The ground mixture was then heated at 140 °C for 1 h under Ar flow (flow rate: 300 mL/min) to remove the excess 3,3′-bpy. The resulting yellow powder was manually collected with a spatula. Yield: 34.8 mg, 91%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C20H16Cu2I2N4: C: 34.65, H: 2.33, N: 8.08. Found: C: 34.99, H: 2.14, N: 8.04.

Synthesis of [Cu<sub>2</sub>I<sub>2</sub>(4,4′-bpy)<sub>2</sub>]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>CuI-4</bold>)Preparation of <bold>CuI-4</bold> as Single Crystals

The synthesis and crystal structure of CuI-4 has been previously reported. However, to compare its crystallographic parameters to those of CuI-3, CuI-4 was synthesized in this study using the following procedure: A DMSO (5 mL) solution of 4,4′-bpy (33 mg, 0.21 mmol) was added to an acetonitrile solution (5 mL) of CuI (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) at 298 K to produce a yellow precipitate. The product was allowed to stand for 1 week at 298 K until red crystals emerged which were suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The afforded red crystals were isolated by filtration, washed with small amounts of acetonitrile and diethyl ether, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 35.2 mg, 92%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C20H16Cu2I2N4: C: 34.65, H: 2.33, N: 8.08. Found: C: 35.00, H: 2.16, N: 8.14.

Thermal Synthesis of <bold>CuI-4</bold>

CuI (20 mg, 0.11 mmol) and 4,4′-bpy (24.8 mg, 0.15 mmol) were mixed and manually ground with a mortar and pestle for 5 min. The mixture was then heated at 140 °C for 1 h under Ar flow (flow rate: 300 mL/min) to promote the coordination polymerization reaction between CuI and 4,4′-bpy and remove the excess 4,4′-bpy. The resulting red powder was manually collected with a spatula. Yield: 37.1 mg, 97%. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C20H16Cu2I2N4: C: 34.65, H: 2.33, N: 8.08. Found: C: 34.46, H: 2.13, N: 7.93.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structures of (top) CuI-3 and (bottom) CuI-4. (a) 2D coordination network structures and (b) packing diagram viewed along the a–c axis for CuI-3 and the c axis for CuI-4. Cu­(I) coordination spheres are depicted as blue tetrahedrons. Brown, light blue, and dark purple ellipsoids represent C, N, and I atoms, respectively; H atoms are omitted for clarity. Displacement parameters are drawn at the 50% probability level. The dotted line in panel (a) illustrates the π–π stacking interaction between two adjacent pyridyl rings.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structures of (top) CuI-3 and (bottom) CuI-4. (a) 2D coordination network structures and (b) packing diagram viewed along the a-c axis for CuI-3 and the c axis for CuI-4. Cu(I) coordination spheres are depicted as blue tetrahedrons. Brown, light blue, and dark purple ellipsoids represent C, N, and I atoms, respectively; H atoms are omitted for clarity. Displacement parameters are drawn at the 50% probability level. The dotted line in panel (a) illustrates the π-π stacking interaction between two adjacent pyridyl rings.

cln_elements.content: Excitation (dashed lines) and emission (solid lines) spectra of (a) CuI-3 and (b) CuI-4 in the solid state at 298 K (red lines) and 77 K (blue lines). The excitation wavelengths for the emission spectra of CuI-3 and CuI-4 were 370 nm at 298 K for both complexes and 422 and 462 nm, respectively, at 77 K. The insets in panels (a) and (b) are the photographs taken under (top) bright field and (bottom) UV light irradiation.
